But that’s the fun and importance of these symbolic items within the books – there’s the actual use and then there’s the symbolic one (and symbolism has many layers). And in this scene, it’s the symbolic use of cloaks that lies beneath the surface text.

In addition, Sansa’s reunion with Jon (and “cloaking”) subsequently ended her marriage to Ramsey and Tyrion and any chance of Littlefinger worming his way in there (and Jon ‘goes against’ all three).

It’s important to note that the first actual act of cloaking between these two, is one for warmth and comfort – the characters are unaware of any potential symbolic meaning in their actions.

3. Jon cloaked by Sansa


Cloaking in weddings is a symbolic and political action, not just for the audience, but for the characters as well. The characters are aware of these symbolic gestures and what they mean, but of course for the audience there is often going to be that extra layer of meaning. Which is what we have here in the final cloaking for Jonsa…so far. 

Jon is the ceremonial wife. 

He enters this “ceremony” with his Night’s Watch’s cloak and then that cloak is removed as Jon resigns from his post from the Night’s Watch – he hands his black cloak with the wooly collar (maiden’s cloak) to Edd in S6E03 “Oathbreaker,” after fulfilling his last duty as Lord Commander. 

In S6E04, “Book of the Stranger” he is reunited with Sansa.

And in S6E05, “The Door” he is wearing his old cloak (the one Sansa wore).

This was his look before he joined the Night’s Watch – so while he is literally wearing a cloak, he is cloakless. Or more accurately for this analogy he’s in-between his maiden’s cloak and bridal cloak.  

His family ties (Night’s Watch) have ended and he is cloaked by Sansa as she gives him the Stark Embroidered Cloak. 

Sidenote: In season 7, Jon has a new cloak – which Sansa might’ve made, but it’s not the same one she made in season 6. I thought it was, until I rewatched Costume Co’s video on Jon Snow’s Costuming. 

Now the Season 6 Cloak is Sansa’s way of including Jon into the Stark family and name – a step towards there being less barriers between the two in matters of birth or status. It’s them, the Starks, battling to take back their home of Winterfell.

Sansa gives Jon the use of her name by not only giving him a proper Stark Cloak, but also the permission to embrace his own Starkness, which he’s been previously denied as a bastard. Which is important.  

Jon’s Stark Cloak is packed with so much symbolic weight.


As Sansa and Jon go together to plea with the other Northern families to help them retake back Winterfell. Sansa can’t do this alone because she is a woman and married to Ramsey – if Jon wasn’t with her, there would’ve been a very good chance someone would’ve returned her to Ramsey.

Jon as Sansa’s “only living” male family member in Westerosi culture gives her protection, not really in the physical sense, Jon and his small entourage can only do so much, but symbolically he has a lot power. 

Sansa by using her Stark name and more importantly dressing Jon in the Stark Cloak (invoking Ned Stark) gives Jon symbolic status. He’s not just a bastard (who has no rights), he’s Ned Stark’s son and therefore deserves to be heard. 

Again, this is all symbolic within the world. 

Sansa as a woman and Ramsey’s wife and Jon being a “turncloak” to the Night’s Watch, neither have any right nor any army to give them any rights or power over Ramsey. 

But yet the other houses do see them and speak to them and even give them respect, not as their liege Lord and Lady, but still more respect than their current statuses allowed them. 

Symbols and political gestures matter so much in this world and can give someone actual power – but only if people believe in them and accept the weight given to these gestures.

Any of the Northern Houses could’ve easily imprisoned Jon and Sansa and given them to Ramsey Bolton (like the Umbers did to Rickon), but the proper political gestures and the symbols Jon and Sansa wear prevents these families from doing so. 

It’s not because those families were far nobler and kinder then the Umbers, but because Sansa and Jon are playing the political (strategic) game. 

Sansa gives Jon a political boost by giving him the cloak.

And Sansa was only able to do this because Jon had previously given her a “boost” by providing safety, comfort and protection and just familial love. 

Littlefinger wasn’t wrong when he said titles have the habit of breeding more titles and that’s also true with political gestures. 

So, in regards to Jon and Sansa there have been Three Cloaking Ceremonies involving the two within the subtext of the show and perhaps in the future books.

Before I finish up, we need to briefly talk about Sansa and Jon’s ‘separate’ involvement with cloaks, ‘independent’ of one another. 

Sansa + Cloaks (books)


I’ve covered a lot of Sansa’s relationship to cloaks already (her multiple cloakings and marriages) but there’s still more. 

As Sansa in her chapters, uses cloaks to help her stay hidden, most notably when she is working with Dontos to escape King’s Landing.

“Sansa threw a plain grey cloak over her shoulders and picked up the knife she used to cut her meat. If it is some trap, better that I die than let them hurt me more, she told herself. She hid the blade under her cloak.” (ACOK, Sansa II)

“Dress warmly, Ser Dontos had told her, and dress dark. She had no blacks, so she chose a dress of thick brown wool. The bodice was decorated with freshwater pearls, though. The cloak will cover them.” (ASOS, Sansa V).

The last quote is interesting, because while Sansa is literally talking about her cloak covering the pearls of her dress, there is another layer to this. Pearls are associated with the Starks.

Sansa’s maiden’s cloak – “a long cloak of white velvet heavy with pearls. A fierce direwolf was embroidered upon it in silver thread.” (ASOS, Sansa III)

“Lord Mace Tyrell came forward to present his gift: a golden chalice three feet tall, with two ornate curved handles and seven faces glittering with gemstones. “Seven faces for Your Grace’s seven kingdoms,” the bride’s father explained. He showed them how each face bore the sigil of one of the great houses: ruby lion, emerald rose, onyx stag, silver trout, blue jade falcon, opal sun, and pearl direwolf.” (ASOS, IV) 

And while pearls aren’t used exclusively for the Starks and their direwolf sigil (far from it), there is a link established between the two before Sansa escapes. 

And just as Sansa covers up the pearls on her dress, she will cover the fact that she is a Stark very soon. 

Finally, Littlefinger discusses the importance of Sansa’s maiden’s cloak and what it could represent –

“When Robert dies, Harry the Heir becomes Lord Harrold, Defender of the Vale and Lord of the Eyrie. Jon Arryn’s bannermen will never love me, nor our silly, shaking Robert, but they will love their Young Falcon … and when they come together for his wedding, and you come out with your long auburn hair, clad in a maiden’s cloak of white and grey with a direwolf emblazoned on the back … why, every knight in the Vale will pledge his sword to win you back your birthright.” (AFFC, Alayne II).

In general, cloaks play a pretty significant part in Sansa’s chapters.

Jon + Cloaks (books)


The most significant cloaks in Jon’s chapters are of course the black cloaks he and his brothers of the Night’s Watch wear. Similar to how the Kingsguard and Gold Cloaks are named and identified by their main garment - Jon and is brothers are called crows by the wildings, because of their black cloaks.

“Jon’s fingers were in the bucket, blood up to the wrist. “Dywen says the wildlings call us crows,” he said uncertainly.” (GOT, Jon VIII)

“The big spearwife narrowed her eyes and said, “If the crow would join the free folk, let him show us his prowess and prove the truth of him.” (ACOK, Jon VIII)

“The girl laughed scornfully. “For one o’ us. D'ya think you’re the first crow ever flew down off the Wall? In your hearts you all want to fly free.” (ASOS, Jon I)

Jon is also called a turncloak, for his time with the wildlings and his relationship with Ygritte. 

“Immaculate in his fur-trimmed cloak and polished boots, Ser Alliser Thorne turned to say, “Here’s the turncloak now, my lord. Ned Stark’s bastard, of Winterfell.” (ASOS, Jon IX) 

“Your father died by the sword, but he was highborn, a King’s Hand. For you, a noose will serve. Ser Alliser, take this turncloak to an ice cell.” (ASOS, Jon IX)

Aside from that, cloaks are really used in Jon’s chapters as part of the first usage of cloaks within the text – the practical and literal. 

“He took his cloak from its hook near the door and shouldered his way out.” (GOT, Jon V)

“They ate cold salt beef, hard bread, and harder cheese, and slept clothed and huddled beneath a pile of cloaks and furs, grateful for each other’s warmth.” (ACOK, Jon VI)

That’s really the main way cloaks are involved in Jon’s chapters, with there being one major exception though, involving a wedding. 

The wedding between Alys Karstark and Sigorn of Thenn. 

Not only does Jon arrange this marriage and give Alys away (which shows him acting as a Lord and King, not a Lord Commander), but he even has a new sigil created, a combination of the Karstark sigil and a symbol of the Thenns. 

“The Thenns had no family arms as was customary amongst the nobles of the Seven Kingdoms, so Jon told the stewards to improvise…The bride’s cloak Sigorn fastened about Lady Alys’s shoulders showed a bronze disk on a field of white wool, surrounded by flames made with wisps of crimson silk. The echo of the Karstark sunburst was there for those who cared to look, but differenced to make the arms appropriate for House Thenn.” (ADWD, Jon X)

While arguably it may be more important to just get these two married, in order to help Alys and bring the wildings further into The North to help deal with the upcoming invasion, the symbolic practices need to be fulfilled to give this marriage actual weight in this world. 

And Jon knows this.

Even though others might think a maiden’s cloak is not important (it is), Jon even has a maiden’s cloak made for Alys – 

“Her maiden’s cloak was the black wool of the Night’s Watch. The Karstark sunburst sewn on its back was made of the same white fur that lined it.” (ADWD, Jon X). 

Jon knows that just having Alys and Sigorn go to Karhold and say they’re married, even with 200 Thenn men, isn’t enough. The two not only had to have gotten married, but believe they are married themselves. 

And for the marriage to be real, the cultural customs need to be fulfilled. That’s why even the hollow weddings go through all the customs. 

And the idea of Jon having a new sigil created for this new house, feeds into my original idea that while Jon might take the Stark name by marrying Sansa, there is more than a good chance that a new sigil will be created for the Starks.

Finally, this wedding matches pretty closely to Sansa’s thoughts of what her wedding should’ve been like.

“She had dreamed of her wedding a thousand times, and always she had pictured how her betrothed would stand behind her tall and strong, sweep the cloak of his protection over her shoulders, and tenderly kiss her cheek as he leaned forward to fasten the clasp.” (ASOS, Sansa III)

“The Magnar all but ripped the maiden’s cloak from Alys’s shoulders, but when he fastened her bride’s cloak about her he was almost tender. As he leaned down to kiss her cheek, their breath mingled.” (ADWD, Jon X)

The wedding that was only possible because of Jon Snow, has an intimate description of the groom and bride that is a close match to Sansa’s dream wedding. 

And similar to how this wedding may not have been Alys’s ideal wedding, Sansa’s wedding to Jon might not be everything she wanted when she was a child, but it will hopefully be the right mix of her dreams meeting reality. 


In conclusion, cloaks matter a lot in the world of Westeros, as simple clothing items to proud and important symbols that the characters wear. Like other clothing, they can emphasize what the characters are trying to say and show about themselves as well as reveal what they are truly about. 

Both Jon and Sansa have importance given to cloaks in their individual chapters in the books as well as in the show, when they are reunited and join forces.

The cloaking ceremony is integral to the weddings of Westeros and what weddings should represent in this world. And with all the less than ideal weddings happening in the story, it’s interesting that while Jon and Sansa haven’t been married, they’ve created their own cloaking ceremonies with their genuine intent to build a new relationship together. 

Their symbolic cloakings have more weight to them than the real weddings that have played out in the story. 

And of course, with the fact that both Jon and Sansa have cloaked the other in a way, leads to a more balance foundation built on equal trust and protection. 

The three cloakings that can be applied to Jonsa are important in their own right, but truthfully, are building to what I believe will be a real and truly proper cloaking ceremony in their future wedding. 

A wedding where Sansa will get to be the happy bride, safe and loved, and Jon will have what he always thought he couldn’t, a wife and a family and the Stark name.
trail.content:
The Cloaking Ceremony is an integral part to weddings across all the different regions of Westeros, and while for the show the ceremony is primarily in the background, both texts still provide an interesting connection in regards to Jon and Sansa and their relationship. 

In my post, Jon Stark, by Marrying Sansa Stark – 

I analyzed the potential relationship and future for Jon and Sansa, the idea being that Jon would take Sansa’s last name when they got married. 

Now in that post, I missed what is an important parallel and step towards Jon taking Sansa’s name – that Sansa has cloaked Jon in “Stark colors” or a cloak embroidered with the Stark sigil, to be more accurate.

Symbolically, a bridal cloak.

Now in the books there’s more cultural significance put on the cloaking ceremony than in the show, but we do see it happening within the show during several weddings.

In fact, only two weddings within the show didn’t have a cloaking ceremony - Robb Stark & Talisa’s wedding and Rhaegar Targaryen & Lyanna Stark’s wedding - two weddings where the couples’ are eloping in secret.

But before we go more into the ceremony, we need to talk about the two main roles cloaks have within the text.  

Firstly, they provide practical use within the world. 

Usually part of the description for a character’s look. Sometimes cloaks are worn just as regular articles of clothing, or they’re worn when a character is trying to hide or disguise themselves or the cloak is simply worn to protect the character from the weather, most notably in the very cold North and so on. 

Secondly, they are symbolic articles

Usually representing either status and or house lineage. Many characters (nobles) wear cloaks with their house colors or sigil or wear a brooch or pin with their house symbol fasten to their cloaks. In addition, the colors of cloaks identify the organization of the wearer – from the Kingsguards’ white cloaks to the City Guard, adeptly named the Gold Cloaks, to the Night’s Watch’s black cloaks (clothing).  

The Cloaking Ceremony is a clear symbolic usage of cloaks, involving two types of cloaks - The Maiden’s Cloak and the Bridal Cloak.

A woman goes into the ceremony wearing a cloak of her own house (maiden’s cloak), but leaves wearing her husbands’ (bridal cloak). 

The idea being the woman sheds the cloak representing her family’s house and her loyalties to them. Then the husband places a cloak representing his house onto the wife, symbolizing she is under his and his family’s protection. 

Sansa even describes the bridal cloak as “the cloak of his protection,” when she thinks about how her wedding should’ve when she is married to Tyrion (Sansa III, ASOS).

In the show, the ceremony is a bit different than in the books – the biggest difference being that there is only the bridal cloak, no maiden’s cloak.

Within the text (book and show) we have seen the cloaking ceremony several times. The snag is that with a decent amount of the weddings we’ve seen, it’s just a ceremony for ceremony sake. The actual meaning is left out as the two main parties, not just the husband and wife, are not being genuine with their intentions. 

It’s a hollow spectacle.


Sansa and Tyrion’s wedding is a good example of the hollow spectacle, minus the more than common gory ending of these ‘false weddings’. 

As neither Sansa nor Tyrion wanted the wedding, but were forced into it – Sansa more than Tyrion. 

So, while it is still a legal wedding and everyone says and does their part – the wedding and the cloaking ceremony are empty acts, nothing more than show.

Now to be fair – Tyrion does honestly swear to protect Sansa. But, the main point is that Sansa as a hostage to the Lannisters is in no place to truly refuse or consent, her agreement to this whole thing is an empty gesture. 

You can do all the motions and say all the words, but there has to be something behind those actions and words for it to actually mean something. 

While the bride’s side (and consent) can be minimized in its importance to the wedding as she’s being given away, it’s the weddings where the bride (and or her family) weren’t being honest with their intentions that leads to these deadly wedding (marriage) ends. The Westerlings. The Freys. The Tyrells. 

Robert and Cersei’s wedding (and marriage) was nothing more than empty ceremony and we saw how well that turned out. 

While the husband is supposed to swear an oath to protect his new wife, the same isn’t true for the wife, and all of these deadly weddings, potentially show the dangers of this uneven ceremony.

In the reverse though, we have Jon and Sansa who haven’t even come close to getting married to one another within the actual text, of either show or book. 

They’re not married and haven’t done a proper and official cloaking ceremony at all, and yet they have, in a way.

Three Cloakings 

Unlike some of the other marriages we’ve seen, both Jon and Sansa’s intentions are genuine as they form a new partnership and relationship with one another. That relationship is partially represented by the actions they take that in-turn create this purely symbolic cloaking ceremony (ceremonies).

Arguably, there are three cloakings that exist in the subtext of the books and tv-show for Jon and Sansa.

1. Sansa Cloaked by the Hound


This is a scene that many people see as Sandor x Sansa (Sansan). For good reason, as he is literally cloaking her in his own cloak, but yet, the subtext implies “Jon Snow.”  

In Book and Season 2, Sansa is stripped and beaten by the King’s Guard on the orders of Joffrey, punishing her for the recent Lannister losses which is put to a stop by Tyrion (ACOK, Sansa III and S2E04, “Garden of Bones”). Tyrion asks for someone to give Sansa something to cover herself with and Sandor Clegane rips off his White Kingsguard cloak for her, which she uses to cover herself.

A clear form of Sandor Clegane cloaking Sansa.

But not just any cloak, a type of cloak that represents a celibate order of men and has been describe as being snow-white several times.

“Yet the huge man at the head of the column, flanked by two knights in the snow-white cloaks of the Kingsguard, seemed almost a stranger to Ned …” (GOT, Eddard I)

“The seven knights of the Kingsguard took the field, all but Jaime Lannister in scaled armor the color of milk, their cloaks as white as fresh-fallen snow.” (GOT, Sansa II)

“Arya recognized the Hound, wearing a snowy white cloak over his dark grey armor, with four of the Kingsguard around him.” (GOT, Arya V)

“Ser Meryn entered from the west side of the yard…His cloak streamed behind him like a field of snow.” (ACOK, Sansa I).

And of course, when Jaime is a prisoner, he brings up the connection of these White Cloaks to Jon Snow, to antagonize Catelyn. 

“His smile cut. “I’ve never lain with any woman but Cersei. In my own way, I have been truer than your Ned ever was. Poor old dead Ned. So who has shit for honor now, I ask you? What was the name of that bastard he fathered?”

Catelyn took a step backward. “Brienne.”

“No, that wasn’t it.” Jaime Lannister upended the flagon. A trickle ran down onto his face, bright as blood. “Snow, that was the one. Such a white name…like the pretty cloaks they give us in the Kingsguard when we swear our pretty oaths.” (ACOK, Catelyn VII).

Furthermore, Sansa later describes the Hound’s cloak that she used to cover herself as being “stained by blood and fire” (ACOK, Sansa VII). 

In the show, as Nattyslove22 points out in their Analysis Here, this is one of the few scenes where we see the Blue Winter Rose that represents Jon Snow.

In seasons 1 and 2, there are blue rose stained glass windows we see several times, specifically in moments that subtly implicate Jon Snow into the scene.

The first time being when Ned refuses to help Robert kill Daenerys and her unborn child – adamant against killing the last remaining Targaryen, because Ned himself has a remaining Targaryen as a member of his family. 

Read Nattyslove22’s post, it’s an interesting bit of foreshadowing within the background details. 

So, during Sansa’s first “cloaking” –

She is cloaked by a snow-white cloak that she later describes with the Targaryen words in the presence of the Blue Winter Rose… not concrete, but these details and implications give one pause. 

However, this one moment just implies Jon, as he himself is not actually a part of this cloaking. At best this scene is foreshadowing.

2. Sansa Wearing Jon’s Cloak


In the show, after Sansa and Jon are reunited, in S6E04 “Book of the Stranger,” we see them in Jon’s chambers by a fireplace.

Sansa is wearing clothing from the Night’s Watch and what seems likely to be Jon’s old cloak - identified by the non-black fur on the shoulders, which is distinct, as in the Night’s Watch all clothes come in black or are dyed black.

Sidenote: While perhaps not intended by the show creators or costume designer, Jon potentially keeping his old cloak would represent the conflict Book Jon experiences, his unwillingness to truly and completely let go of his Stark past and family – despite never having the name himself. 

In any regard, Sansa is wearing a cloak given to her by Jon, that Jon is later seen wearing. 

This is a small detail in the show that doesn’t draw a lot of attention to itself, but it is significant. As this one scene tells the audience that Sansa is under Jon’s protection and care - “the cloak of his protection”. She’s safe now. 

Brienne and Theon both play a part in making this ceremony happen, in fact they’re a part of the ceremony – as they both take on the role of the one to “walk Sansa down the aisle” and reunite her with Jon.


Theon was given the job to walk Sansa down another aisle and give her away to Ramsey Bolton, and in the books, Theon is given the same authority over Jeyne Poole when she is fake Arya.

While Theon isn’t a member of the Stark family, his previous relationship to them was enough to give him authority to give Sansa (and fake Arya) away – though that authority was just a twisted cultural gesture by Ramsey.

The important thing is that while Theon was assigned the authority for the hollow wedding ceremony between Sansa and Ramsey (similar to Joffrey giving her away to Tyrion), when it counts and the actions actually mean something, Theon delivered.

By delivering Sansa so to speak, as he does his best to get Sansa to Castle Black, so she can be reunited with Jon.

Brienne was sworn to protect Sansa (and Arya) and was given that authority by Catelyn Stark. While not a male member of Sansa’s family, it’s not a stretch to say that as Catelyn and Sansa’s one true knight, sworn into their service that Brienne has a role to play and fulfills it by “walking Sansa down the aisle and giving her away” or literally bringing her to Castle Black and reuniting her with Jon. 

This ‘ceremony’ while not literal is the one where it matters because the gestures aren’t hollow – because while neither Theon or Brienne have the traditional Westerosi or legal authority over Sansa – they have her best intentions at heart and genuinely want to deliver her to someone who can protect and care for her.

Sansa has only been reunited with Jon in the show, but it doesn’t seem crazy that in the books Jon and Sansa will not only be reunited, but this cloaking scene or something similar will take place. With more weight and emphasis put on it – albeit subtly.

The idea of Jon noticing Sansa is cold and putting his cloak around her to help her get warm and overall feel safe seems very possible.  

The actual scene itself and the potential scene in the future books are nothing more than the first use of cloaks being utilized on the surface – a cloak being used for the sake of warmth.

But that’s the fun and importance of these symbolic items within the books – there’s the actual use and then there’s the symbolic one (and symbolism has many layers). And in this scene, it’s the symbolic use of cloaks that lies beneath the surface text.

It’s important to note that the first actual act of cloaking between these two, is one for warmth and comfort – the characters are unaware of any potential symbolic meaning in their actions.

Finally, Littlefinger discusses the importance of Sansa’s maiden’s cloak and what it could represent –

“When Robert dies, Harry the Heir becomes Lord Harrold, Defender of the Vale and Lord of the Eyrie. Jon Arryn’s bannermen will never love me, nor our silly, shaking Robert, but they will love their Young Falcon … and when they come together for his wedding, and you come out with your long auburn hair, clad in a maiden’s cloak of white and grey with a direwolf emblazoned on the back … why, every knight in the Vale will pledge his sword to win you back your birthright.” (AFFC, Alayne II).

In general, cloaks play a pretty significant part in Sansa’s chapters.

Jon + Cloaks (books)


The most significant cloaks in Jon’s chapters are of course the black cloaks he and his brothers of the Night’s Watch wear. Similar to how the Kingsguard and Gold Cloaks are named and identified by their main garment - Jon and is brothers are called crows by the wildings, because of their black cloaks.

“Jon’s fingers were in the bucket, blood up to the wrist. “Dywen says the wildlings call us crows,” he said uncertainly.” (GOT, Jon VIII)

“The big spearwife narrowed her eyes and said, “If the crow would join the free folk, let him show us his prowess and prove the truth of him.” (ACOK, Jon VIII)

“The girl laughed scornfully. “For one o’ us. D'ya think you’re the first crow ever flew down off the Wall? In your hearts you all want to fly free.” (ASOS, Jon I)

Jon is also called a turncloak, for his time with the wildlings and his relationship with Ygritte. 

“Immaculate in his fur-trimmed cloak and polished boots, Ser Alliser Thorne turned to say, “Here’s the turncloak now, my lord. Ned Stark’s bastard, of Winterfell.” (ASOS, Jon IX) 

“Your father died by the sword, but he was highborn, a King’s Hand. For you, a noose will serve. Ser Alliser, take this turncloak to an ice cell.” (ASOS, Jon IX)

Aside from that, cloaks are really used in Jon’s chapters as part of the first usage of cloaks within the text – the practical and literal. 

“He took his cloak from its hook near the door and shouldered his way out.” (GOT, Jon V)

“They ate cold salt beef, hard bread, and harder cheese, and slept clothed and huddled beneath a pile of cloaks and furs, grateful for each other’s warmth.” (ACOK, Jon VI)

That’s really the main way cloaks are involved in Jon’s chapters, with there being one major exception though, involving a wedding. 

The wedding between Alys Karstark and Sigorn of Thenn. 

Not only does Jon arrange this marriage and give Alys away (which shows him acting as a Lord and King, not a Lord Commander), but he even has a new sigil created, a combination of the Karstark sigil and a symbol of the Thenns. 

“The Thenns had no family arms as was customary amongst the nobles of the Seven Kingdoms, so Jon told the stewards to improvise…The bride’s cloak Sigorn fastened about Lady Alys’s shoulders showed a bronze disk on a field of white wool, surrounded by flames made with wisps of crimson silk. The echo of the Karstark sunburst was there for those who cared to look, but differenced to make the arms appropriate for House Thenn.” (ADWD, Jon X)

While arguably it may be more important to just get these two married, in order to help Alys and bring the wildings further into The North to help deal with the upcoming invasion, the symbolic practices need to be fulfilled to give this marriage actual weight in this world. 

And Jon knows this.

Even though others might think a maiden’s cloak is not important (it is), Jon even has a maiden’s cloak made for Alys – 

“Her maiden’s cloak was the black wool of the Night’s Watch. The Karstark sunburst sewn on its back was made of the same white fur that lined it.” (ADWD, Jon X). 

Jon knows that just having Alys and Sigorn go to Karhold and say they’re married, even with 200 Thenn men, isn’t enough. The two not only had to have gotten married, but believe they are married themselves. 

And for the marriage to be real, the cultural customs need to be fulfilled. That’s why even the hollow weddings go through all the customs. 

And the idea of Jon having a new sigil created for this new house, feeds into my original idea that while Jon might take the Stark name by marrying Sansa, there is more than a good chance that a new sigil will be created for the Starks.

Finally, this wedding matches pretty closely to Sansa’s thoughts of what her wedding should’ve been like.

“She had dreamed of her wedding a thousand times, and always she had pictured how her betrothed would stand behind her tall and strong, sweep the cloak of his protection over her shoulders, and tenderly kiss her cheek as he leaned forward to fasten the clasp.” (ASOS, Sansa III)

“The Magnar all but ripped the maiden’s cloak from Alys’s shoulders, but when he fastened her bride’s cloak about her he was almost tender. As he leaned down to kiss her cheek, their breath mingled.” (ADWD, Jon X)

The wedding that was only possible because of Jon Snow, has an intimate description of the groom and bride that is a close match to Sansa’s dream wedding. 

And similar to how this wedding may not have been Alys’s ideal wedding, Sansa’s wedding to Jon might not be everything she wanted when she was a child, but it will hopefully be the right mix of her dreams meeting reality. 


In conclusion, cloaks matter a lot in the world of Westeros, as simple clothing items to proud and important symbols that the characters wear. Like other clothing, they can emphasize what the characters are trying to say and show about themselves as well as reveal what they are truly about. 

Both Jon and Sansa have importance given to cloaks in their individual chapters in the books as well as in the show, when they are reunited and join forces.

The cloaking ceremony is integral to the weddings of Westeros and what weddings should represent in this world. And with all the less than ideal weddings happening in the story, it’s interesting that while Jon and Sansa haven’t been married, they’ve created their own cloaking ceremonies with their genuine intent to build a new relationship together. 

Their symbolic cloakings have more weight to them than the real weddings that have played out in the story. 

And of course, with the fact that both Jon and Sansa have cloaked the other in a way, leads to a more balance foundation built on equal trust and protection. 

The three cloakings that can be applied to Jonsa are important in their own right, but truthfully, are building to what I believe will be a real and truly proper cloaking ceremony in their future wedding. 

A wedding where Sansa will get to be the happy bride, safe and loved, and Jon will have what he always thought he couldn’t, a wife and a family and the Stark name.
trail.content_abstract:
The Cloaking Ceremony is an integral part to weddings across all the different regions of Westeros, and while for the show the ceremony is primarily in the background, both texts still provide an interesting connection in regards to Jon and Sansa and their relationship. 

In my post, Jon Stark, by Marrying Sansa Stark – 

I analyzed the potential relationship and future for Jon and Sansa, the idea being that Jon would take Sansa’s last name when they got married. 

Now in that post, I missed what is an important parallel and step towards Jon taking Sansa’s name – that Sansa has cloaked Jon in “Stark colors” or a cloak embroidered with the Stark sigil, to be more accurate.

Symbolically, a bridal cloak.

Now in the books there’s more cultural significance put on the cloaking ceremony than in the show, but we do see it happening within the show during several weddings.

In fact, only two weddings within the show didn’t have a cloaking ceremony - Robb Stark & Talisa’s wedding and Rhaegar Targaryen & Lyanna Stark’s wedding - two weddings where the couples’ are eloping in secret.

But before we go more into the ceremony, we need to talk about the two main roles cloaks have within the text.  

Firstly, they provide practical use within the world. 

Usually part of the description for a character’s look. Sometimes cloaks are worn just as regular articles of clothing, or they’re worn when a character is trying to hide or disguise themselves or the cloak is simply worn to protect the character from the weather, most notably in the very cold North and so on. 

Secondly, they are symbolic articles

Usually representing either status and or house lineage. Many characters (nobles) wear cloaks with their house colors or sigil or wear a brooch or pin with their house symbol fasten to their cloaks. In addition, the colors of cloaks identify the organization of the wearer – from the Kingsguards’ white cloaks to the City Guard, adeptly named the Gold Cloaks, to the Night’s Watch’s black cloaks (clothing).  

The Cloaking Ceremony is a clear symbolic usage of cloaks, involving two types of cloaks - The Maiden’s Cloak and the Bridal Cloak.

A woman goes into the ceremony wearing a cloak of her own house (maiden’s cloak), but leaves wearing her husbands’ (bridal cloak). 

The idea being the woman sheds the cloak representing her family’s house and her loyalties to them. Then the husband places a cloak representing his house onto the wife, symbolizing she is under his and his family’s protection. 

Sansa even describes the bridal cloak as “the cloak of his protection,” when she thinks about how her wedding should’ve when she is married to Tyrion (Sansa III, ASOS).

In the show, the ceremony is a bit different than in the books – the biggest difference being that there is only the bridal cloak, no maiden’s cloak.

Within the text (book and show) we have seen the cloaking ceremony several times. The snag is that with a decent amount of the weddings we’ve seen, it’s just a ceremony for ceremony sake. The actual meaning is left out as the two main parties, not just the husband and wife, are not being genuine with their intentions. 

It’s a hollow spectacle.


Sansa and Tyrion’s wedding is a good example of the hollow spectacle, minus the more than common gory ending of these ‘false weddings’. 

As neither Sansa nor Tyrion wanted the wedding, but were forced into it – Sansa more than Tyrion. 

So, while it is still a legal wedding and everyone says and does their part – the wedding and the cloaking ceremony are empty acts, nothing more than show.

Now to be fair – Tyrion does honestly swear to protect Sansa. But, the main point is that Sansa as a hostage to the Lannisters is in no place to truly refuse or consent, her agreement to this whole thing is an empty gesture. 

You can do all the motions and say all the words, but there has to be something behind those actions and words for it to actually mean something. 

While the bride’s side (and consent) can be minimized in its importance to the wedding as she’s being given away, it’s the weddings where the bride (and or her family) weren’t being honest with their intentions that leads to these deadly wedding (marriage) ends. The Westerlings. The Freys. The Tyrells. 

Robert and Cersei’s wedding (and marriage) was nothing more than empty ceremony and we saw how well that turned out. 

While the husband is supposed to swear an oath to protect his new wife, the same isn’t true for the wife, and all of these deadly weddings, potentially show the dangers of this uneven ceremony.

In the reverse though, we have Jon and Sansa who haven’t even come close to getting married to one another within the actual text, of either show or book. 

They’re not married and haven’t done a proper and official cloaking ceremony at all, and yet they have, in a way.

blog.title: Chicago Diva
blog.description: I'm a fan of Jon, the North, and the Starks.  Not a Jonsa, but an ally because they are nice, rational people unlike other parts of GOT fandom that will remain nameless.  (Apparently I'm also a sexist crazy person for having bad, ungood opinions about Daenerys Targaryen!  And I also set up alts and post anonymous comments and talk to myself on AO3...  Sarc off.  Yeah, fandom is pissing me off right now.)

tags: now we are back to subjects have no rights
What you are arguing about Sansa and the North applies to Jon as well
There is still no title called king consort and consorts have no power
summary: Part three of responding to a long, unhinged Dany-stan screed
title: Part three of responding to a long, unhinged Dany-stan screed
body:
In which we continue a discussion with @aweseeds and try to work through his/her gibberish.

Are the North servants of Jon and the Starks?

Jon’s position is elected.  As LF pointed out and the Northern lords reminded Sansa, Jon can be forced to abdicate.  It is a much weaker kingship than a united Westeros was and the lords appear to have more power.  I do think that Jon views the North as his servants and thinks they should all kneel in submission to his new Kween.  This will come back to bite him in Season 8 and I believe that he will end up being stripped of power by the lords.

Jon’s position is absolutely not elected.  There were no other candidates for King.  The Northerners didn’t even consider Sansa, the last known trueborn Stark as a candidate.

The fact that the North chose Jon over his sister means that it is elected.  Jon has no rights to Winterfell as a bastard.  Sansa should have been declared queen based on the rules of inheritance and Bran before her.

Jon was not serving some four-year term as King. 

But he was still elected.  Just because it is for life doesn’t mean that it isn’t elected.

Any plan to overthrow him by his very subjects is TREASON.  

So now you are arguing that subjects have no right to disagree with their monarch or defy him or her even a bad monarch who they disagree with.

Jon’s kingship was based on proclamation by his then subjects, his blood connection to previous kings, and successfully defeating the House that ruled the North.  As Lyanna Mormont said “Ned Stark’s blood runs through his veins.” (This is true even thought he is not Ned’s son, he still has as much Stark blood as Sansa or any of the Stark children.) Those who want Sansa to be Queen have to base any claim on the fact that she is a Stark.

And?  People vote for those with certain family names all the time in democracies.  Ever heard of the Kennedys?

But Jon was elected partially because of his own merit.  (Of course, the show should have done a better job showing he had merit, but still.)  He has lost the confidence of his lords because of his disastrous decisions as king.  The lords prefer Sansa particularly because she is doing a competent job ruling them. 

That is why Sansa’s undermining Jon in front of his bannermen was so politically terrible.  She accused him of not offering any benefit to being loyal to him & not punishing treason when he refused to punish the Umber & Karstark children for their father’s sins, and abandoning his people when he decided to lead a diplomatic mission to gain an important ally and resources the North desperately needed for its very survival against the Night King, who would slaughter every Northerner and use them as soldiers to kill more people. When his very sister was no qualms about publicly opposing his decisions instead of respecting his authority, some lords might think they can speak treason when they disagree with their King.

So now a ruler’s subjects have no right to speak out in public against him or her.  You will agree that this applies to Jon with regards to Daenerys.  Using your own logic, he has no right to speak against her in public.  After all, that would really cause the North to rebel against their new Targaryen tyrant.

Yes, Jon’s subjects are expected to kneel before Queen Daenerys because their King has knelt and been named Warden of the North. This is the exact situation as when Torrhen Stark knelt to Aegon I, except that Daenerys did not go to war against the North.

What if the Northern lords don’t want to be slaves of the Targaryens?  Using your own logic, they have every right to say no thanks.  Or don’t they now.  As I pointed out above, Jon is a servant who cannot defy Daenerys.  If shut up and kneel applies to the North, it applies to Jon with regards to Dany.

Instead she sworn all of her armies & resources to defend the North against the Army of the Dead without Jon having knelt or sworn to her.  

This is the most hilarious of the arguments by Dany-stans.  No, she doesn’t deserve absolute wealth and power for helping the North.  Superheroes don’t demand rewards in return for their service.

I disagree Jon will be stripped on any power by the Northerners.  

Well, the few pictures we have of Season 8 show Dany’s newest pet without his Stark insignia, so methinks that he is stripped of power.

He said he was going to Dragonstone to try to convince Daenerys to fight with the North against the Night King and to mine the dragonglass for weapons.  He is returning with everything he hoped to gain. 

He went there a king and returns Dany’s newest mistress.  Going from being an equal ruler to a pet mistress isn’t returning with what the North wants.  The North wants independence.

He remains their leader. Daenerys has named him her Warden and supports him in this position as well. 

Warden is a toothless position in the books.  The powerful (but still servile) position is of Lord Paramount.  Sansa as Lady Paramount now holds way more power than Jon.  Jon is basically Daario.  He is a servant who by your own words has no right to defy the Queen.

Do you think the Northerners will see all of those warriors and weapons Jon brought to give them the best chance of survive and hate him and put Sansa in charge or something? No.

They want to be free so why not?  Or are they not allowed freedom and must be the slaves of the Targaryens so Queen Snowflake can have her tiara.

I disagree Jon will be stripped on any power by the Northerners.  

Well, the few pictures we have of Season 8 show Dany’s newest pet without his Stark insignia, so methinks that he is stripped of power.

He said he was going to Dragonstone to try to convince Daenerys to fight with the North against the Night King and to mine the dragonglass for weapons.  He is returning with everything he hoped to gain. 

He went there a king and returns Dany’s newest mistress.  Going from being an equal ruler to a pet mistress isn’t returning with what the North wants.  The North wants independence.

He remains their leader. Daenerys has named him her Warden and supports him in this position as well. 

Warden is a toothless position in the books.  The powerful (but still servile) position is of Lord Paramount.  Sansa as Lady Paramount now holds way more power than Jon.  Jon is basically Daario.  He is a servant who by your own words has no right to defy the Queen.

Do you think the Northerners will see all of those warriors and weapons Jon brought to give them the best chance of survive and hate him and put Sansa in charge or something? No.

They want to be free so why not?  Or are they not allowed freedom and must be the slaves of the Targaryens so Queen Snowflake can have her tiara.

summary: as promised, here are some photos of our cosplays from the weekend - featuring sansa, margaery, and arya!  we all got stopped so...
caption:
as promised, here are some photos of our cosplays from the weekend - featuring sansa, margaery, and arya! 

we all got stopped so many times for photos and compliments (there was even a guy who could barely speak because of a sore throat but made sure to come over and say how much he loved our costumes - honestly, what a sweetheart!) there weren’t many game of thrones cosplays so people appreciated our efforts! i would walk down the corridors and here people say variations of: “that’s sansa stark!”, “she’s the lady of winterfell!”, “lady stark (bows)”, “my queen!” and i wanted to die of happiness!

also thoughts and feelings: should i upload the last picture and tag sophie on twitter in the hopes the feeling is mutual when it comes to “leaks” of sansa’s death in s8??

summary: Jonsa Story ~Warrior~ Game of Thrones [Sansa POV]  My first video about the relationship (as siblings or lovers, it’s your...
caption:
Jonsa Story ~Warrior~ Game of Thrones [Sansa POV]

My first video about the relationship (as siblings or lovers, it’s your choice) between Jon & Sansa. I wanted to make a chronological summary of their story.

I really enjoy see them comfort each other, laugh together, argue, scream at each other, not understand other, be reconciled, show their love, miss each other, take revenge from those who hurt them and so on.

It’s such a human relationship, full of imperfection but with deep feelings.
